result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

03:53 PM Defendant in court with Attorney John K Smerlinski.  Intern Raphael Torrez with ADA Patrick Winter appeared for the State of Wisconsin.   State moved for counts 1 and 2 to be found transactionally related. No objection. Court grants motion to find counts 1 and 2 transactionally related.  Witness JC sworn and testified. Direct exam by the State. Venue established.  Cross exam by Atty Smerlinski. Redirect by the State. DE identified. Recross by Atty Smerlinski. Witness excused. Motions by the State. Response by Atty Smerlinski. Reply by the State. Court made findings and probable cause found.
